natural problem: What is the probability that the same number will be facing up on each of three standard six-sided dice that are tossed simultaneously? Express your answer as a common fraction.
natural solution: The results on the three dice are independent of each other, so we compute the probability for each die and then multiply the probabilities. The first die does not have to be a particular number. There are 6 possible numbers, but any number will work, so the probability is $\frac{6}{6}=1$.

The second die must be the same number as the first die, which is one number out of the 6 possible outcomes, so the probability is $\frac{1}{6}$. The third die must also be the same number as the first die, so the probability is also $\frac{1}{6}$.
The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability_same_number :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_same_number = (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6)"
shows  "probability_same_number = 1 / 36"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the same number will be facing up on each of three standard six-sided dice that are tossed simultaneously? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{36}
 ### Proof
 The results on the three dice are independent of each other, so we compute the probability for each die and then multiply the probabilities. The first die does not have to be a particular number. There are 6 possible numbers, but any number will work, so the probability is $\frac{6}{6}=1$.
 The second die must be the same number as the first die, which is one number out of the 6 possible outcomes, so the probability is $\frac{1}{6}$. The third die must also be the same number as the first die, so the probability is also $\frac{1}{6}$.
 The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability_same_number :: real
assumes h0 : "probability_same_number = (1 / 6) * (1 / 6) * (1 / 6)"
shows  "probability_same_number = 1 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the probability of getting the same number on three dice rolls. Each die has 6 sides. The final answer is $\frac{1}{6} \times \frac{1}{6} \times \frac{1}{6} = \frac{1}{216}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>(a, b, c). 1 / (6 * 6 * 6))"
shows  "probability (a, a, a) = 1 / 36"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>(a, b, c). 1 / (6 * 6 * 6))"

a_1.informal problem: Given a probability function $P(a, b, c) = \frac{1}{6^3}$, what is the probability that all three variables are equal (i.e., $P(a, a, a)$)? The final answer is $\frac{1}{36}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>x. 1 / (6^x))"
and h1 : "three_dice = (\<lambda>x. probability x * probability x * probability x)"
shows  "three_dice 3 = 1 / 36"
a_2.formal solution:

 The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "rat \<Rightarrow> rat"
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda>x. 1 / (6^x))"
and h1 : "three_dice = (\<lambda>x. probability x * probability x * probability x)"

a_2.informal problem: Suppose the probability of rolling a specific number on a single 6-sided die is $\frac{1}{6^x}$. What is the probability of rolling that same number three times in a row, given as a fraction? The final answer is $\frac{1}{36}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> (num_favorable_outcomes :: nat) (total_outcomes :: nat). (num_favorable_outcomes / total_outcomes))"
shows  "probability (6, 216) = 1 / 36"

fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> (num_favorable_outcomes :: nat) (total_outcomes :: nat). (num_favorable_outcomes / total_outcomes))"

a_3.informal problem: Find the probability of an event, given that there are 6 favorable outcomes and 216 total outcomes. The final answer is $\frac{1}{36}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> x. 1 / 6)"
and h1 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. borel) (\<lambda>_. h0) {1, 2, 3}"
shows  "prob {(a, b, c). a = b \<and> b = c \<and> a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6}} = 1 / 36"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the same number will be facing up on each of three standard six-sided dice that are tossed simultaneously? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{36}
 ### Proof
 The results on the three dice are independent of each other, so we compute the probability for each die and then multiply the probabilities. The first die does not have to be a particular number. There are 6 possible numbers, but any number will work, so the probability is $\frac{6}{6}=1$.
 The second die must be the same number as the first die, which is one number out of the 6 possible outcomes, so the probability is $\frac{1}{6}$. The third die must also be the same number as the first die, so the probability is also $\frac{1}{6}$.
 The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "probability = (\<lambda> x. 1 / 6)"
and h1 : "indep_vars (\<lambda>_. borel) (\<lambda>_. h0) {1, 2, 3}"
shows  "prob {(a, b, c). a = b \<and> b = c \<and> a \<in> {1..6} \<and> b \<in> {1..6} \<and> c \<in> {1..6}} = 1 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: In a game with three independent dice rolls, each die has 6 faces with equal probability of 1/6 for each face. What is the probability of all three dice showing the same number? The final answer is 1/36.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 1 \<longrightarrow> probability x = x"
and h1 : "probability (1/6) = 1/6"
shows  "probability (1/6 * 1/6) = 1/36"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the same number will be facing up on each of three standard six-sided dice that are tossed simultaneously? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{36}
 ### Proof
 The results on the three dice are independent of each other, so we compute the probability for each die and then multiply the probabilities. The first die does not have to be a particular number. There are 6 possible numbers, but any number will work, so the probability is $\frac{6}{6}=1$.

 The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 1 \<longrightarrow> probability x = x"
and h1 : "probability (1/6) = 1/6"
shows  "probability (1/6 * 1/6) = 1/36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: If the probability function $p(x) = x$ for all $x$ in the interval $[0,1]$, and the probability of a specific event is $\frac{1}{6}$, what is the probability of both events happening simultaneously? The final answer is $\frac{1}{36}$.

a_8.formal solution:

 What is the probability that the same number will be facing up on each of three standard six-sided dice that are tossed simultaneously? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{36}

 The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda>n. n / 6) powr 3"
shows  "P 1 = 1 / 36"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the value of the function $P(n) = (\frac{n}{6})^3$ when $n = 1$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{36}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "0 \<le> p"
and h1 : "p \<le> 1"
and h2 : "p = 1 / 6 * 1 / 6 * 1 / 6"
shows  "p = 1 / 36"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the probability that the same number will be facing up on each of three standard six-sided dice that are tossed simultaneously? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final Answer is \frac{1}{36}

 The probability that all three dice will have the same number is then $1\times\frac{1}{6}\times\frac{1}{6}=\boxed{\frac{1}{36}}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
